Identification.LongTitle: On Board Trains Occupational Health and Safety Regulations

Provision.Text: Her Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Labour, pursuant to sections 82* and 83* and subsection 106(2)* of the Canada Labour Code, is pleased hereby to approve the annexed Regulations respecting occupational safety and health of employees on trains while in operation made under Part IV of the Canada Labour Code by the Minister of Labour on the recommendation of the Canadian Transport Commission, effective April 2, 1987.

Section.Text: In these Regulations,

Definition.Text: Act means Part II of the Canada Labour Code; (Loi)
CSA means the Canadian Standards Association; (CSA)
electrical equipment means equipment for the generation, distribution or use of electricity; (outillage électrique)
maintenance of way equipment means track motor cars and other rolling stock used for maintaining rails and tracks; (véhicule d’entretien)
on-board accommodation means living, eating or sleeping quarters provided on rolling stock by an employer for the accommodation of employees; (logement à bord)

oxygen deficient atmosphere means an atmosphere in which there is less than 18% by volume of oxygen at a pressure of one atmosphere or in which the partial pressure of oxygen is less than 135 mm Hg; (air à faible teneur en oxygène)
protection equipment means safety materials, equipment, devices and clothing; (équipement de protection)
qualified person means, in respect of a specified duty, a person who, because of his knowledge, training and experience, is qualified to perform that duty safely and properly; (personne qualifiée)

rolling stock means a locomotive, caboose, self-propelled car, box car, tank car, maintenance of way equipment, snow-plow, flanger and other mobile equipment designed to move on wheels on rails or tracks; (matériel roulant)
toilet room means a room that contains a toilet. (cabinet de toilette)

Section.Text: These Regulations are prescribed for the purposes of sections 125, 125.1, 125.2 and 126 of the Act.

These Regulations apply to any person who is not an employee but who performs for an employer to which these Regulations apply activities whose primary purpose is to enable the person to acquire knowledge or experience, and to the employer, as if that person were an employee of the employer, and every provision of these Regulations must be read accordingly.
These Regulations apply in respect of employees on trains while in operation and in respect of all persons granted access to such trains by the employer.

An employer’s keeping and maintenance of health and safety records and records of exposure to hazardous substances shall be done in such a manner that the records are readily available for examination by the Minister and by the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative for the work place to which they apply.

In the event of an inconsistency between any standard incorporated by reference in these Regulations and any other provision of these Regulations, that other provision of these Regulations shall prevail to the extent of the inconsistency.
In this Part, elevating device means an escalator, elevator or other device for moving passengers or freight and that is installed on rolling stock. (appareil de levage)
No elevating device shall be used or operated with a load in excess of the load that it was designed and installed to move safely.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), no elevating device shall be used or placed in service while any safety device attached thereto is inoperative.
Subject to subsection (3), no safety device attached to an elevating device shall be altered, interfered with or rendered inoperative.
Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply to an elevating device or a safety device that is being inspected, tested, repaired or maintained by a qualified person.

Section.Text: Every elevating device and every safety device attached thereto shall be inspected and tested by a qualified person to determine that it is in a safe operating condition and is capable of carrying any load that is likely to be imposed on it

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before the elevating device and the safety device attached thereto are placed in service;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: after an alteration to the elevating device or a safety device attached thereto; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: once every 12 months.

Subsection.Text: A record of each inspection and test made in accordance with section 2.4 shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be signed by the qualified person who made the inspection and test;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: include the date of the inspection and test and the identification and location of the elevating device and safety device that were inspected and tested; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: set out the observations of the qualified person inspecting and testing the elevating device and safety device on the safety of the devices.

Subsection.Text: Every record referred to in subsection (1) shall be kept by the employer for a period of two years after the date on which it is signed in accordance with paragraph (1)(a).

Section.Text: Repair and maintenance of elevating devices and safety devices attached thereto shall be performed by a qualified person appointed by the employer.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: task position means a position at which a visual task is performed. (poste de travail)
VDT means a visual display terminal. (TEV)

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Part, 1 lx is equal to 0.0929 foot candle.
The levels of lighting prescribed in this Part shall, where reasonably practicable, be provided by a lighting system installed by the employer.
Where it is not reasonably practicable to comply with subsection (1), the employer shall provide portable lanterns that give the prescribed levels of lighting.

Section.Text: For the purposes of this Part, the average level of lighting at a task position or in an area shall be determined

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by making one measurement at four different places that are representative of the level of lighting at the task position or that, in an area, are representative of the level of lighting 1 m above the floor of the area; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by dividing the aggregate of the results of those measurements by four.

Section.Text: The level of lighting in an area referred to in Column I of an item of Schedule I to this Part shall be not less than the level set out in Column II.
The level of lighting in an area referred to in Column I of an item of Schedule II to this Part shall be not less than the level set out in Column II.

Subsection.Text: The average level of lighting at a task position set out in Column I of Schedule III to this Part shall not be more than the level set out in Column II.
Reflection glare on a VDT screen shall be limited so that an employee at a task position is able to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: read every portion of any text displayed on the screen; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: see every portion of the visual display on the screen.

Subsection.Text: Where there is a failure in the lighting system in an area through which an employee passes in carrying out procedures referred to in paragraph 13.7(2)(a), emergency lighting shall be available in the area for immediate use.
The emergency lighting referred to in subsection (1) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where reasonably practicable, operate automatically in the event of a failure of the lighting system; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide an average level of lighting of not less than 10 lx.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: A-weighted sound pressure level means a sound pressure level as determined by a measurement system which includes an A-weighting filter that meets the requirements set out in the International Electrotechnical Commission’s International Standard IEC 61672-1, first edition 2002-05, entitled Electroacoustics – Sound Level Meters. (niveau de pression acoustique pondérée A)
dBA means decibel A-weighted and is a unit of A-weighted sound pressure level. (dBA)

noise exposure level (Lex,8) means the level equal to 10 times the logarithm to the base 10 of the time integral over any 24-hour period of a squared A-weighted sound pressure divided by 8, the reference sound pressure being 20 µPa. (niveau d’exposition (Lex,8))

sound level meter means an instrument for measuring levels of sound and impulse sound that meets the requirements set out in the International Electrotechnical Commission’s International Standard IEC 61672-1, first edition 2002-05, entitled Electroacoustics – Sound Level Meters. (sonomètre)

sound pressure level means the level equal to 20 times the logarithm to the base 10 of the ratio of the root mean square pressure of a sound to the reference sound pressure of 20 µPa, expressed in decibels. (niveau de pression acoustique)

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Part, the exposure of an employee to sound shall be measured using an instrument that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is recommended for that measurement in clause 4.3 of CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z107.56-06, Procedures for the Measurement of Occupational Noise Exposure, as amended from time to time; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements for such an instrument set out in clause 4 of that Standard.

Subsection.Text: The exposure of an employee to sound shall be measured in accordance with clauses 5, 6.4.1, 6.4.4, 6.5.2, 6.5.4, 6.6.2 and 6.6.4 of the Standard that is referred to in paragraph (1)(a).

For the purposes of this Part, the measurement and calculation of the noise exposure level (Lex,8) to which an employee is exposed shall take into account the exposure of the employee to A-weighted sound pressure levels of 74 dBA or more.

The measurement and calculation of the noise exposure level (Lex,8) referred to in subsection (3) may also take into account the exposure of the employee to A-weighted sound pressure levels that are less than 74 dBA.

If an employee in a work place may be exposed to an A-weighted sound pressure level of 84 dBA or more for a duration that is likely to endanger the employee’s hearing, the employer shall, without delay,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: appoint a qualified person to carry out an investigation of the degree of exposure; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: notify the work place committee or the health and safety representative of the investigation and the qualified person’s name.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), the measurement of the A-weighted sound pressure level in a work place shall be performed instantaneously, during normal working conditions, using the slow response setting of a sound level meter.
In the investigation referred to in subsection (1), the following matters shall be considered:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the sources of sound in the work place;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the A-weighted sound pressure levels to which the employee is likely to be exposed and the duration of such exposure;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the methods being used to reduce this exposure;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: whether the exposure of the employee is likely to exceed the limits set out in section 4.4; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: whether the employee is likely to be exposed to a noise exposure level (Lex,8) of 84 dBA or more.

Subsection.Text: On completing the investigation and after consulting with the work place committee or the health and safety representative, the qualified person shall make, sign and date a written report that contains their

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: observations respecting the matters set out in subsection (3);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: recommendations respecting the measures that should be taken in order to comply with sections 4.4 to 4.8; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: recommendations respecting the use of hearing protectors by employees who are exposed to a noise exposure level (Lex,8) of 84 dBA or more but not more than 87 dBA.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall keep the report at a location that is accessible to affected employees for a period of 10 years after the date of the report.
If the report states that an employee is likely to be exposed to a noise exposure level (Lex,8) of 84 dBA or more, the employer shall, without delay,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: post and keep posted a copy of the report in a conspicuous place accessible to the employee; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide the employee with written information that describes the hazards associated with exposure to high levels of sound.

Section.Text: No employee in a work place shall be exposed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in any 24-hour period, to an A-weighted sound pressure level set out in column I of the schedule to this Part for a duration of exposure that exceeds the applicable duration set out in column II; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at any time, to a noise exposure level (Lex,8) of more than 87 dBA.

Section.Text: If an employee’s exposure to sound exceeds a limit set out in section 4.4, an employer shall, if it is reasonably practicable to do so, by engineering controls or other physical means other than hearing protectors, reduce the employee’s exposure to sound to a level that does not exceed that limit.

If it is not reasonably practicable, without providing hearing protectors, for an employer to limit the exposure of an employee to whom section 4.4 applies to sound to a level that does not exceed the limits set out in that section, the employer shall, without delay,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: make a report in writing to the Minister setting out the reasons why it is not reasonably practicable to do so; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide a copy of the report to the work place committee or the health and safety representative.

Subsection.Text: An employer who is required to make a report under section 4.6 shall, as soon as practicable, provide every employee whose exposure to sound is likely to exceed a limit set out in section 4.4 with a hearing protector that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements set out in CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z94.2-02, Hearing Protection Devices – Performance, Selection, Care, and Use, as amended from time to time; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prevents the employee from being exposed to a level of sound that exceeds a limit set out in section 4.4.

Subsection.Text: If an employer provides a hearing protector to an employee, the employer shall, in consultation with the work place committee or the health and safety representative, develop a program to train the employee in the fit, care and use of the hearing protector and shall implement the program.

If an employer grants a person who is not an employee access to a work place where the person is likely to be exposed to a level of sound that exceeds a limit set out in section 4.4, the employer shall ensure that the person uses a hearing protector that meets the requirements set out in the Standard that is referred to in paragraph (1)(a).

If an employee may be exposed to an A-weighted sound pressure level of more than 87 dBA at a work place, the employer shall, in conspicuous places within the work place, post and keep posted signs warning of a potentially hazardous level of sound.

In order to determine whether an employee may be exposed to an A-weighted sound pressure level of more than 87 dBA at a work place, the measurement of the A-weighted sound pressure level shall be performed instantaneously, during normal working conditions, using the slow response setting of a sound level meter.

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: control device means a device that will safely disconnect electrical equipment from its source of energy; (dispositif de commande)
guarded means, in respect of electrical equipment, equipment that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: covered, shielded, enclosed or otherwise protected in a manner that prevents injury to an employee who touches or goes near the equipment, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in a place inaccessible to employees. (protégé)

Subsection.Text: Where work, other than the work referred to in subsection (2), is performed on electrical equipment, the employer shall adopt and implement Part VIII of the Canada Occupational Health and Safety Regulations.
Where an employee is required to throw switches, change light bulbs or fuses or perform other work that requires no electrical training, the following procedures apply:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where electrical equipment is live or may become live, no employee shall work on the equipment unless the employer has instructed the employee in procedures that are safe for work on live conductors;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to paragraph (c), where an employee is working on or near electrical equipment that is live or may become live, the electrical equipment shall be guarded; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where it is not practicable for electrical equipment referred to in paragraph (b) to be guarded, the employer shall take measures to protect the employee from injury by insulating the equipment from the employee or the employee from ground.

Subsection.Text: Every control device shall be so designed and located as to permit quick and safe operation at all times.
The path of access to every electrical switch, control device or meter shall be free from obstruction.

Where an electrical switch or other control device controlling the supply of electrical energy to electrical equipment is operated only by a person authorized to do so by the employer, the switch or control device shall be fitted with a locking device that only the authorized person can activate.

Section.Text: In this Part, food preparation area includes an area used for the storage of food.

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall maintain each on-board accommodation and food preparation area used by employees in a clean and sanitary condition.
On-board accommodation and food preparation areas shall be so used by employees that the accommodation or areas remain as clean and in as sanitary a condition as is possible.

Section.Text: All janitorial work that may cause dusty or unsanitary conditions shall be carried out in a manner that will prevent the contamination of the air by dust or other substances injurious to health.
All on-board accommodation and toilet rooms shall be constructed and maintained in a manner that prevents adverse health and safety conditions.

Subsection.Text: In rolling stock on which there is on-board accommodation, the food preparation area shall be separated from the sleeping quarters.
In every on-board accommodation,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: garbage disposal facilities shall be provided to prevent the accumulation of garbage; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: potable water, heating, ventilation and sanitary sewage systems shall be provided.

Subsection.Text: Each garbage container that is used for solid or liquid waste in a work place shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with a tight-fitting cover;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be so constructed that it can easily be cleaned and maintained in a sanitary condition; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be leak-proof.

Subsection.Text: Each garbage container referred to in subsection (1) shall be emptied at least once every day that it is used.

An employer shall ensure that each enclosed part of a work place and each on-board accommodation, toilet room and food preparation area is constructed, equipped and maintained in a manner that will prevent the entrance of vermin.

If vermin enter any enclosed part of a work place or any on-board accommodation, toilet room or food preparation area, the employer shall without delay take all steps necessary to eliminate the vermin and prevent any further entries.

Section.Text: No person shall use on-board accommodation, a toilet room or a food preparation area for the purpose of storing equipment unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a storage closet fitted with a door is provided in the on-board accommodation, toilet room or food preparation area; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the equipment is secured in a manner that protects employees from injury.

Section.Text: In each on-board accommodation, toilet room and food preparation area, the temperature, measured 1 m above the floor in the centre of the room or area, shall, where reasonably practicable, be maintained at a level of not less than 18°C and not more than 29°C.

Subsection.Text: In each on-board accommodation, toilet room and food preparation area, the floors, partitions and walls shall be so constructed that they can be easily washed and maintained in a sanitary condition.
The floor and lower 150 mm of any walls and partitions that are in contact with the floor in any food preparation area or toilet room shall be water-tight and impervious to moisture.
Where reasonably practicable, every employer shall provide a toilet room on rolling stock, other than rolling stock designed for transporting freight and maintenance of way equipment.
Where it is not reasonably practicable to provide a toilet room pursuant to subsection (1), the employer shall provide a toilet room that is readily accessible to employees and is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: off the rolling stock; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: coupled to the rolling stock.

Section.Text: Every toilet room shall be fitted on the inside with a locking device that can be opened from the outside in an emergency.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), where a toilet room is provided pursuant to section 6.11 and employees of both sexes are employed at the same work place, an employer shall provide a separate toilet room for employees of each sex.
An employer may provide only one toilet room for employees of both sexes if the toilet room is completely enclosed with solid material that is non-transparent from the outside.

Where separate toilet rooms are provided for employees of each sex, each toilet room shall be equipped with a door that is clearly marked to indicate the sex of the employees for whom the room is provided.
Subject to subsection (2), the toilet provided in a toilet room shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a locomotive, be of the self-contained chemical flush type; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a caboose, be of such a type and construction that waste is not deposited on the track bed or on any part of the caboose.

Subsection.Text: Outside flush or dryhopper type toilets that are suitable for year-round use may be used in a locomotive or caboose if they were installed in that locomotive or caboose prior to May 1, 1969.
Subject to subsection (2), every toilet room shall be provided with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: toilet paper on a holder or in a dispenser; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: hand cleaning and drying supplies.

Subsection.Text: An employer may provide toilet paper and hand cleaning and drying supplies to each individual employee.
In or adjacent to every toilet room, a non-combustible container shall be provided for the disposal of hand cleaning and drying supplies.
A covered container or a bag that is impervious to moisture shall be provided for the disposal of sanitary napkins in each toilet room for the use of female employees.

Section.Text: Every employer shall, where reasonably practicable, provide at each washbasin in a toilet room hot and cold running water.
Hot water that is provided to employees for personal washing shall be maintained at a temperature of not less than 35°C and not more than 43°C and shall not be heated by mixing with steam.
In every toilet room that contains a washbasin, the employer shall provide soap or another cleaning agent in a dispenser at the washbasin.

Potable water that is provided to employees for drinking, personal washing and food preparation shall meet the standards set out in the Guidelines for Canadian Drinking Water Quality – Summary Table, prepared by the Federal-Provincial-Territorial Committee on Drinking Water of the Federal-Provincial-Territorial Committee on Health and the Environment and published by the Department of Health, as amended from time to time.
Where it is necessary to transport water for drinking, personal washing or food preparation, only sanitary portable water containers shall be used.
Where a portable storage container for drinking water is used,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the container shall be securely covered and closed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the container shall be used only for the purpose of storing potable water;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the container shall not be stored in a toilet room; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the container is not a single-use storage container, water shall be drawn from it by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a tap,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a ladle used only for the purpose of drawing water from the container, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any other means that precludes the contamination of the water.

Section.Text: Except where drinking water is supplied by a drinking fountain or a single-use portable storage container, sanitary single-use drinking cups shall be provided.
Any ice that is added to drinking water or used for the contact refrigeration of foodstuffs shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: made from potable water; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: stored and handled in a manner that prevents contamination.

Heading.TitleText: Preparation, Handling, Storage and Serving of Food

Subsection.Text: Foods that require refrigeration to prevent them from becoming hazardous to health shall be maintained at a temperature of 4°C or lower.
Where foods stored by the employer for consumption by employees require freezing to prevent them from becoming hazardous to health, the foods shall be maintained at a temperature of -11°C or lower.

Section.Text: All equipment and utensils that come into contact with food shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: designed to be easily cleaned;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: smooth, free from cracks, crevices, pitting or unnecessary indentations; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: cleaned to maintain their surfaces in a sanitary condition.

Section.Text: No person shall eat, prepare or store food

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in a place where a hazardous substance may contaminate food, dishes or utensils;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in a toilet room; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in any other place where food is likely to be contaminated.

Subsection.Text: No food waste or garbage shall be stored in a food preparation area.
The employer shall ensure that an employee who is responsible for handling food waste and garbage or for removing it from a food preparation area does so in accordance with subsections (3) to (5).
Wet food waste and garbage shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: disposed of by mechanical grinders or choppers connected to sewage disposal lines; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: held in leak-proof, non-absorptive, easily-cleaned containers with tight-fitting covers in a separate enclosed area or container until removal for disposal.

Subsection.Text: Dry food waste and garbage shall be removed or incinerated.
Food waste and garbage containers shall be fitted with covers and the food waste and garbage shall be removed as frequently as is necessary to prevent unsanitary conditions.
Food waste and garbage containers shall be cleaned and disinfected in an area separate from the food preparation area each time they are emptied.
Subject to subsection (2), where reasonably practicable, the exhaust system for on-board accommodation, a toilet room or a food preparation area

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall be of a mechanical type; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall not be connected with any other exhaust or air supply system.

Subsection.Text: The exhaust system for on-board accommodation, a toilet room or a food preparation area may be connected to the exhaust duct of another room at the exhaust fan inlet if it is connected in such a manner that an exchange of air between those rooms or areas cannot occur.

Section.Text: Clothing storage facilities shall be provided by the employer for the storage of overcoats and other clothes not worn by employees while they are working.
In any on-board accommodation provided as sleeping quarters, each employee shall be provided with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a separate bed or bunk that is not part of a unit that is more than double-tiered and is so constructed that it can be easily cleaned and disinfected;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a mattress, pillow, blanket and bed cover that are kept in a clean and sanitary condition; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: at least once a week, clean laundered sheets and a pillow case.

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: airborne asbestos fibres means asbestos fibres that are longer than 5 μm (micrometres) with an aspect ratio equal to or greater than 3:1 and that are carried by the air; (fibres d’amiante aéroportées)
asbestos means actinolite, amosite, anthophyllite, chrysotile, crocidolite and tremolite in their fibrous form; (amiante)
asbestos-containing material means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any article that is manufactured and contains 1% or more asbestos by weight at the time of manufacture or that contains a concentration of 1% or more asbestos as determined in accordance with Method 9002 set out in the document entitled NIOSH Manual of Analytical Methods, published by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, as amended from time to time, or in accordance with a scientifically proven method used to collect and analyze a representative sample of the material, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any material that contains a concentration of 1% or more asbestos as determined in accordance with Method 9002 set out in the document entitled NIOSH Manual of Analytical Methods, published by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, as amended from time to time, or in accordance with a scientifically proven method used to collect and analyze a representative sample of the material; (matériau contenant de l’amiante)

Definition.Text: clearance air sampling means the action of taking samples to determine if the concentration of airborne asbestos fibres inside an enclosure is below the limit referred to in section 7.20 to permit the dismantling of a containment system; (échantillonnage de l’air après décontamination)

containment system means an isolation system that is designed to effectively contain asbestos fibre within a designated work area where asbestos-containing material is handled, removed, encapsulated or enclosed; (système de confinement)

encapsulation means the treatment of an asbestos-containing material with a sealant that penetrates the material and binds the asbestos fibres together, and the treatment of the surface of the asbestos-containing material with a sealant that creates a membrane on the surface, to prevent the release of asbestos fibres into the air; (encapsulation)

enclosure means a physical barrier such as drywall, plywood or metal sheeting that, as part of the containment system, isolates asbestos-containing material from adjacent areas in a building to prevent the release of airborne asbestos fibres into those areas; (encloisonnement)
friable means, in respect of asbestos-containing material, that the material, when dry, can be easily crumbled or powdered by hand pressure; (friable)

glove bag means a polyethylene or polyvinyl chloride bag that is affixed around an asbestos-containing source and that permits asbestos-containing material to be removed while minimizing the release of airborne asbestos fibres into the work place; (sac à gants)

hazard information means, in respect of a hazardous substance, information on the proper and safe storage, handling, use and disposal of the hazardous substance, including information relating to the health and physical hazards that it presents; (renseignements sur les risques)

HEPA filter means a high-efficiency particulate air filter that has been tested to ensure efficiency equal to or exceeding 99.97% for removal of airborne particles having a mean aerodynamic diameter of 0.3 µm (micrometres) from the air; (filtre HEPA)

high-risk activity means an activity that involves the handling or disturbance of friable asbestos-containing material or is carried out in proximity to friable asbestos-containing material, that requires a high level of control to prevent exposure to excessive concentrations of airborne asbestos fibres and that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the removal or disturbance of more than 1 m2 of friable asbestos-containing material in a work place, even if the activity is divided into smaller jobs,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the spray application of a sealant to a friable asbestos-containing material,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the cleaning or removal of air-handling equipment, other than filters, in a building that has sprayed-on fireproofing or sprayed-on thermal insulation that is asbestos-containing material,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the repair, alteration or demolition of all or part of a kiln, metallurgical furnace or similar structure that contains asbestos-containing material,

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the breaking, cutting, drilling, abrading, grinding, sanding or vibrating of non-friable asbestos-containing material, if the activity is carried out by means of power tools that are not attached to dust-collecting devices equipped with HEPA filters, and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the repair, alteration or demolition of all or part of a building in which asbestos is or was used in the manufacture of products, unless the asbestos was cleaned up and removed; (activité à risque élevé)

Definition.Text: lower explosive limit means the lower limit of flammability of a chemical agent or a combination of chemical agents at ambient temperature and pressure, expressed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for a gas or vapour, as a percentage in air by volume, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for dust, as the weight of dust per volume of air; (limite explosive inférieure)

Definition.Text: low-risk activity means an activity that involves the handling of asbestos-containing material or is carried out in proximity to non-friable asbestos-containing material and that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the installation or removal of ceiling tiles that are made of non-friable asbestos-containing material and cover an area of less than 7.5 m2,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the installation or removal of other non-friable asbestos-containing material, if the material is not being broken, cut, drilled, abraded, ground, sanded or vibrated and dust is not being generated,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the breaking, cutting, drilling, abrading, grinding, sanding or vibrating of non-friable asbestos-containing material, if the material is wetted to control the spread of dust or fibres and the activity is carried out only by means of non-powered hand-held tools, and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the removal of less than 1 m² of drywall in which joint cement containing asbestos has been used; (activité à faible risque)

Definition.Text: moderate-risk activity means an activity that involves the handling of asbestos-containing material or is carried out in proximity to friable asbestos-containing material, that is not otherwise classified as a low-risk activity or high-risk activity and that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the removal of all or part of a false ceiling to gain access to a work area, if asbestos-containing material is likely to be found on the surface of the false ceiling,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the removal or disturbance of 1 m2 or less of friable asbestos-containing material during repair, alteration, maintenance or demolition work in a work place,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the enclosure of friable asbestos-containing material,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the application of tape, sealant or other covering to pipe or boiler insulation that is asbestos-containing material,

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the removal of ceiling tiles that are asbestos-containing material, if the tiles cover an area of greater than 2 m2 and are removed without being broken, cut, drilled, abraded, ground, sanded or vibrated,

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the breaking, cutting, drilling, abrading, grinding, sanding or vibrating of non-friable asbestos-containing material, if the material is not wetted to control the spread of dust or fibres and the activity is carried out only by means of non-powered hand-held tools,

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the removal of 1 m2 or more of drywall in which joint cement that is asbestos-containing material has been used,

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the breaking, cutting, drilling, abrading, grinding, sanding or vibrating of non-friable asbestos-containing material, if the activity is carried out by means of power tools that are attached to dust-collecting devices equipped with HEPA filters,

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the removal of insulation that is asbestos-containing material from a pipe, duct or similar structure using a glove bag, and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the cleaning or removal of filters used in air-handling equipment in a building that has sprayed-on fireproofing that is asbestos-containing material; (activité à risque modéré)

Definition.Text: product identifier has the same meaning as in subsection 1(1) of the Hazardous Products Regulations; (identificateur de produit)
readily available means, in respect of a document, present and easily accessible at the work place at all times; (facilement accessible)
supplier has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Hazardous Products Act; (fournisseur)

work activity means any low-risk activity, moderate-risk activity or high-risk activity or any activity that is ancillary to that activity, and the supervision of that activity and that ancillary activity. (activité de travail)

Section.Text: This Part does not apply to the handling or transportation of dangerous goods to which the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992 and the regulations made under that Act apply.

An employer shall keep and maintain a record of all hazardous substances that, in the work place, are used, produced, handled, or stored for use in the work place, and may either keep and maintain a record in each work place or keep and maintain in one work place a centralized record in respect of several work places.

Subsection.Text: If there is a likelihood that the health or safety of an employee in a work place is or may be endangered by exposure to a hazardous substance, the employer shall, without delay,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: appoint a qualified person to carry out an investigation in that regard; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: notify the work place committee or the health and safety representative of the investigation and the qualified person’s name.

Subsection.Text: In the investigation, the following matters shall be considered:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the chemical, biological and physical properties of the hazardous substance;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the routes of exposure to the hazardous substance;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the acute and chronic effects on health of exposure to the hazardous substance;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of the hazardous substance to be handled;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the manner in which the hazardous substance is stored, used, handled and disposed of;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the control methods used to eliminate or reduce exposure of employees to the hazardous substance;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the concentration or level of the hazardous substance to which an employee is likely to be exposed;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: whether the concentration of an airborne chemical agent is likely to be greater than 50% of the value referred to in paragraph 7.20(1)(a) for that chemical agent or whether the level of ionizing or non-ionizing radiation is likely to be greater than any applicable limit referred to in subsection 7.23(2) or (3); and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: whether the level referred to in paragraph (g) is greater than any maximum applicable level set out in Part III or less than any minimum applicable level set out in that Part.

Section.Text: On completing the investigation and after consulting with the work place committee or the health and safety representative,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the qualified person shall make, sign and date a written report that contains their

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: observations respecting the matters set out in subsection 7.3(2), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: recommendations respecting the measures that should be taken in order to comply with sections 7.6 to 7.23, including recommendations respecting sampling and testing methods; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the employer shall develop and maintain a written procedure for the control of the concentration or level of the hazardous substance in the work place and make it readily available for examination by employees in any form, as determined in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative.

Section.Text: The employer shall keep the report for a period of 30 years after the date of the report.

Subsection.Text: No person shall use a hazardous substance for any purpose in a work place where it is reasonably practicable to substitute for it a substance that is not a hazardous substance.

Where a hazardous substance is to be used for any purpose in a work place and an equivalent substance that is less hazardous is available to be used for that purpose, the equivalent substance shall be substituted for the hazardous substance where reasonably practicable.

Section.Text: Every ventilation system used to control the concentration of an airborne hazardous substance shall be so designed, constructed and installed that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the concentration of the airborne hazardous substance does not exceed the values and percentages referred to in sections 7.20 and 7.21; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if there is no value or percentage set out in respect of the airborne hazardous substance, its concentration is not hazardous to the health or safety of employees.

Section.Text: Every hazardous substance stored, handled or used in a work place shall be stored, handled or used in a manner whereby the hazard related to that substance is reduced to a minimum.

Subject to section 7.11, if a hazardous substance is stored, handled or used in a work place, any hazard resulting from that storage, handling or use shall be confined to as small an area as practicable.

Every container for a hazardous substance that is used in a work place shall be designed and constructed in such a way that it protects employees from any health or safety hazard that is caused by the hazardous substance.

The quantity of a hazardous substance used or processed in a work place shall, to the extent that is practicable, be limited to the quantity required for use or processing in the work place in one work day.

If, in a work place, a hazardous substance is capable of combining with another substance to form an ignitable combination and there exists a hazard of ignition of the combination by static electricity, the employer shall comply with the standards set out in the 2007 edition of the United States National Fire Protection Association publication NFPA 77 entitled Recommended Practice on Static Electricity.
Every assembly of pipes, pipe fittings, valves, safety devices, pumps, compressors and other fixed equipment that is used for transferring a hazardous substance from one location to another shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: marked, by labelling, colour-coding, placarding or any other mode, to identify the hazardous substance being transferred and, if appropriate, the direction of the flow;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: fitted with valves and other control and safety devices to ensure its safe operation; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: adequate for its intended purpose having regard to the corrosiveness, pressure, temperature and other properties of the hazardous substance transferred therein.

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall, in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative, develop and implement an employee education and training program with respect to hazard prevention and control at the work place.
The employee education and training program shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the education and training of each employee who handles or is exposed to or who is likely to handle or be exposed to a hazardous substance, with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the product identifier of the hazardous substance,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: all hazard information disclosed by the supplier or by the employer on a safety data sheet or label,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: all hazard information of which the employer is aware or ought to be aware,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the observations referred to in subparagraph 7.4(a)(i),

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the information disclosed on a safety data sheet referred to in section 7.25 and the purpose and significance of that information, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of hazardous products in the work place, the information required to be disclosed on a safety data sheet and on a label under Division III and the purpose and significance of that information;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the education and training of each employee who operates, maintains or repairs an assembly of pipes referred to in section 7.15, with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: every valve and other control and safety device connected to the assembly of pipes,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures to follow for the proper and safe use of the assembly of pipes, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the significance of the labelling, colour-coding, placarding or other modes of identification that are used; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the education and training of each employee who is referred to in paragraph (a) or (b), with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures to follow to implement sections 7.8, 7.9 and 7.11,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures to follow for the safe storage, handling, use and disposal of hazardous substances, including procedures to be followed in an emergency involving a hazardous substance, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures to follow if an employee is exposed to a hazardous substance in gas, liquid, solid, vapour, fume, mist, fog or dust form that escapes from processing equipment, from control emission equipment or from a hazardous substance into the work place.

Subsection.Text: An employer shall, in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative, review, and if necessary, revise the employee education and training program referred to in subsection (1)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least once a year;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whenever there is a change in conditions in respect of the hazardous substances in the work place; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whenever new hazard information in respect of a hazardous substance in the work place becomes available to the employer.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall keep a written record of the education and training given to each employee referred to in paragraphs 7.16(2)(a) to (c)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: readily available for examination by employees in any form, as determined in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for two years after the day on which the employee ceases

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to handle or be exposed to or to be likely to handle or be exposed to the hazardous substance, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to operate, maintain or repair the assembly of pipes.

Subsection.Text: The record shall include the name of the employee who was educated and trained and the date of the education and training.
Where the report referred to in section 7.4 contains a recommendation for a medical examination, the employer may consult a physician regarding that recommendation.
Where the employer

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: consults a physician pursuant to subsection (1) and the physician confirms the recommendation for a medical examination, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: does not consult a physician pursuant to subsection (1),

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the employer shall not permit an employee to work with the hazardous substance in the work place until a physician, acceptable to the employee, has examined the employee and declared the employee fit for work with the hazardous substance.

Subsection.Text: Where an employer consults a physician pursuant to subsection (1), the employer shall keep a copy of the decision of the physician with the report referred to in section 7.4.
The cost of a medical examination referred to in subsection (2) shall be borne by the employer.
No employee shall be exposed to a concentration of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an airborne chemical agent, other than airborne asbestos fibres, in excess of the value for that chemical agent adopted by the American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists in its publication entitled Threshold Limit Values (TLVs) and Biological Exposure Indices (BEIs), as amended from time to time; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an airborne hazardous substance, other than a chemical agent, that is hazardous to the health or safety of the employee.

Subsection.Text: An employer shall ensure that an employee’s exposure to a concentration of airborne asbestos fibres is as close to zero as is reasonably practicable, but in any event the employer shall ensure that the concentration is not in excess of the value for airborne asbestos fibres adopted by the American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists in its publication entitled Threshold Limit Values (TLVs) and Biological Exposure Indices (BEIs), as amended from time to time.

If there is a likelihood that the concentration of an airborne chemical agent may exceed the value referred to in paragraph (1)(a), the concentration of airborne asbestos fibres may exceed zero or that there is a concentration of an airborne hazardous substance that is hazardous to the health and safety of the employee, air samples shall be taken by a qualified person and the concentration of the chemical agent, airborne asbestos fibres or hazardous substance shall be determined

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with the standards set out in the United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health publication entitled NIOSH Manual of Analytical Methods, 5th edition, dated 2003;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with a method used to collect and analyze a representative sample of the chemical agent with accuracy and with detection levels at least equal to those which would be obtained if the standards referred to in paragraph (a) were used; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if no specific standards for the chemical agent are set out in the publication referred to in paragraph (a) and no method that meets the requirements of paragraph (b) exists, in accordance with a scientifically proven method used to collect and analyze a representative sample of the chemical agent.

Subsection.Text: A record of each test made pursuant to subsection (2) shall be kept by the employer for three years after the date of the test.
A record referred to in subsection (3) shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date, time and location of the test;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the chemical agent for which the test was made;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the sampling and testing method used;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the result obtained; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name and occupation of the qualified person who made the test.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), the concentration of an airborne chemical agent or combination of airborne chemical agents in a work place shall be less than 50 per cent of the lower explosive limit of the chemical agent or combination of chemical agents.

Where a source of ignition may ignite the concentration of an airborne chemical agent or combination of airborne chemical agents in a work place, that concentration shall not exceed 10 per cent of the lower explosive limit of the chemical agent or combination of chemical agents.

Section.Text: Compressed air, gas or steam shall not be used for blowing dust or other substances from structures, machinery or materials if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: there is a risk of any person being directly exposed to the jet or if a fire, explosion, injury or health hazard is likely to result from that use; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that use would result in either a concentration of an airborne chemical agent that is in excess of the values referred to in paragraph 7.20(1)(a) or subsection 7.20(1.1) or a concentration of an airborne chemical agent or combination of airborne chemical agents that is in excess of the maximum concentration set out in subsection 7.21(1) or (2).

Subsection.Text: Compressed air shall not be used for cleaning clothing contaminated with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: asbestos; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: another airborne chemical agent with an exposure limit referred to in paragraph 7.20(1)(a) that is lower than 1 mg/m3.

Subsection.Text: If compressed air is used to clean any other clothing,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: eye protectors that meet the standards set out in CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z94.3-07, Eye and Face Protectors, as amended from time to time, shall be worn; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: either the maximum compressed air pressure in the pipeline shall be 69 kPa (10 psi) or a safety nozzle limiting the air pressure to no more than 69 kPa (10 psi) shall be used.

Subsection.Text: If a device that is capable of producing and emitting energy in the form of ionizing or non-ionizing radiation is used in a work place, the employer shall apply the limits set out in Limits of Human Exposure to Radiofrequency Electromagnetic Energy in the Frequency Range from 3 kHz to 300 GHz – Safety Code 6 (2009), published by the Department of Health, as amended from time to time.

If an employee works on or near a device that is capable of emitting nuclear energy, the employer shall ensure that the employee’s exposure to nuclear energy does not exceed the radiation dose limits set out in the Radiation Protection Regulations.

The employer shall ensure that no employee, other than a nuclear energy worker as defined in section 2 of the Nuclear Safety and Control Act, is exposed in the course of any year to a concentration of radon that on average, over the year, is higher than 800 Bq/m3.

Heading.Label: DIVISION II
Heading.TitleText: Hazardous Substances Other than Hazardous Products

Subsection.Text: If asbestos-containing material is present in a work place and there is the potential for a release of asbestos fibres or employee exposure to asbestos fibres, an employer shall ensure that the qualified person who is carrying out a hazard investigation under section 7.3 takes into consideration the type of asbestos, the condition of the asbestos-containing material, the friability of the asbestos-containing material, the accessibility to and likelihood of damage to the asbestos-containing material and the potential for the release of asbestos fibres or employee exposure to asbestos fibres.

At the completion of an investigation carried out under section 7.3, the employer shall ensure that a readily available record of the location, friability and condition of the asbestos-containing material and the type of asbestos contained in the asbestos-containing material is kept and maintained for examination by employees and is in any form as determined in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative.

Section.Text: Before undertaking any work activity that involves asbestos-containing material, an employer shall, in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative, develop, implement and administer an asbestos exposure control plan that requires the employer to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that a hazardinvestigation under section 7.3 has been carried out by a qualified person and, in the event that there is a change in the work activity, review any report that was prepared as a result of the investigation and, if necessary, have a qualified person carry out another investigation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that a qualified person classifies the work activity as a low-risk activity, moderate-risk activity or high-risk activity;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that all asbestos-containing material present in the work place that is exposed or that will be disturbed is identified by signs and labels or by any other effective manner;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that all friable asbestos-containing material present in the work place is controlled by removal, enclosure or encapsulation or by any other effective manner to prevent employee exposure to asbestos;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that procedures and control measures for moderate-risk activities and high-risk activities are developed and implemented; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: develop and implement an employee education and training program that is specific to asbestos-containing material.

Section.Text: If an employee who is undertaking automotive service procedures may be exposed to asbestos from friction material or dust arising from that material, an employer shall ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the use of compressed air, brushes or similar means to dry-remove friction material dust from automotive assemblies is prohibited; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: signs to advise employees of the hazards and required precautions are posted in service work areas where friction material is handled or dust arising from that material is generated.

Heading.TitleText: Asbestos Dust, Waste and Debris Removal

Subsection.Text: During any work activities that involve friable asbestos-containing materials, an employer shall ensure that the following activities are carried out frequently and at regular intervals as determined by a qualified person, at the end of each work shift and immediately after the work is completed:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all asbestos dust, waste and debris are removed by vacuuming with a vacuum cleaner that is equipped with a HEPA filter, damp-mopping or wet-sweeping the area that is contaminated with the asbestos dust, waste or debris; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any drop sheets that are contaminated with asbestos dust, waste or debris are wetted.

Subsection.Text: All asbestos dust, waste or debris and any drop sheets that are contaminated with asbestos dust, waste or debris shall be placed in a container referred to in section 7.23.11.

Section.Text: If a glove bag is used for the removal of asbestos insulation from pipes, ducts and similar structures, an employer shall ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the glove bag is sealed to prevent the release of asbestos fibres into the work area;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the glove bag is inspected for damage or defects immediately before it is attached to the pipe, duct or similar structure and at regular intervals during its use;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all waste from asbestos-containing material that is on surfaces is washed to the bottom of the glove bag and all exposed asbestos-containing material is encapsulated when it is inside the glove bag;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the glove bag is evacuated using a vacuum cleaner that is equipped with a HEPA filter to remove the air inside the bag prior to the removal of the glove bag; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: after the glove bag is removed, all exposed surfaces are cleaned with a damp cloth and a vacuum cleaner that is equipped with a HEPA filter.

Subsection.Text: Before leaving a work area that is contaminated with asbestos-containing material, an employee shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if their protective clothing is to be reused, decontaminate the clothing with a damp cloth or a vacuum cleaner that is equipped with a HEPA filter before taking the clothing off; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if their protective clothing is not to be reused, place the clothing in a container referred to in section 7.23.11.

Subsection.Text: An employer shall provide employees with a facility reserved for washing their hands and face, and employees shall wash their hands and face using that facility before leaving a work area that is contaminated with asbestos-containing material.

Section.Text: As soon as practicable after any work activity that involves asbestos-containing material is completed, an employee shall clean reusable tools, equipment, rigid barriers and portable enclosures that are contaminated with asbestos with a damp cloth or a vacuum cleaner that is equipped with a HEPA filter.

Subsection.Text: An employer shall ensure that a qualified person takes air samples to test for airborne asbestos fibres

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the vicinity of the containment system during any work activity that involves asbestos-containing material and, in the case of a work activity that lasts longer than 24 hours, at least daily;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the clean room during removal and clean-up operations and, in the case of removal and clean-up operations that last longer than 24 hours, at least daily; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in contaminated areas that are inside the containment system as necessary during removal and clean-up operations.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall ensure that the following air samples are taken:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: two samples for every area in an enclosure that is 10 m2 or less;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: three samples for every area in an enclosure that is more than 10 m2 and not more than 500 m2; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: five samples for every area in an enclosure that is more than 500 m2.

Subsection.Text: Within 24 hours after obtaining the air sampling test results, the employer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: post a copy of the results in a conspicuous place in the work place; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: make the results available to the policy committee, if any, the work place committee and the health and safety representative.

Subsection.Text: Before dismantling a containment system and after all asbestos dust, waste and debris have been cleaned up, removed or encapsulated, an employer shall ensure that clearance air samples are taken inside the enclosure and that the concentration of airborne asbestos fibres is determined in accordance with Method 7400 set out in the document entitled NIOSH Manual of Analytical Methods, published by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, as amended from time to time, or in accordance with a scientifically proven method used to collect and analyze a representative sample of airborne asbestos fibres.
When conducting clearance air sampling, the employer shall ensure that forced air is used inside the enclosure to dislodge any asbestos fibres from all surfaces and keep them airborne.
Clearance air sampling shall be taken until the concentrations of airborne asbestos fibres do not exceed the values referred to in subsection 7.20(1.1).

Section.Text: Within 24 hours after obtaining the clearance air sampling test results, the employer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: post a copy of the results in a conspicuous place in the work place; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: make the results available to the policy committee, if any, the work place committee and the health and safety representative, and provide a copy of the results to the Minister.

Heading.TitleText: Containers for Asbestos Dust, Waste and Debris

Section.Text: Containers for the containment of asbestos dust, waste and debris and asbestos-containing material shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: dust-tight;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: suitable to contain asbestos dust, waste or debris;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: impervious to asbestos;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: identified as containing asbestos dust, waste or debris;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: cleaned with a damp cloth or a vacuum cleaner that is equipped with a HEPA filter immediately before being removed from the work area; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: removed from the work place frequently and at regular intervals as determined by a qualified person.

Section.Text: Every container of a hazardous substance, other than a hazardous product, that is stored, handled or used in the work place shall be labelled in a manner that discloses clearly

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the substance; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the hazardous properties of the substance.

Section.Text: If a safety data sheet in respect of a hazardous substance, other than a hazardous product, that is stored, handled or used in the work place may be obtained from the supplier of the hazardous substance, the employer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: obtain a copy of the safety data sheet; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep a copy of the safety data sheet readily available in the work place for examination by employees in any form, as determined in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Division.

Definition.Text: bulk shipment has the same meaning as in subsection 5.5(1) of the Hazardous Products Regulations. (expédition en vrac)
container means any package or receptacle, including a bag, barrel, bottle, box, can, cylinder, drum and storage tank. (contenant)
hazardous waste means a hazardous product that is acquired or generated for recycling or recovery or is intended for disposal. (résidu dangereux)
significant new data has the same meaning as in subsection 5.12(1) of the Hazardous Products Regulations. (nouvelles données importantes)
supplier label means a label prepared by a supplier that discloses any information elements required by the Hazardous Products Act. (étiquette du fournisseur)

supplier safety data sheet means a safety data sheet prepared by a supplier that discloses any information elements required by the Hazardous Products Act. (fiche de données de sécurité du fournisseur)
work place label means a label prepared by an employer in accordance with this Division. (étiquette du lieu de travail)
work place safety data sheet means a safety data sheet prepared by an employer in accordance with subsection 7.30(1). (fiche de données de sécurité du lieu de travail)

Subsection.Text: This Division does not apply in respect of any

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: tobacco or a tobacco product as defined in section 2 of the Tobacco and Vaping Products Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: manufactured article as defined in section 2 of the Hazardous Products Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: wood or a product made of wood.

Subsection.Text: This Division, other than section 7.38, does not apply in respect of hazardous waste.

Heading.TitleText: Safety Data Sheets and Labels in Respect of Certain Hazardous Products

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2) and section 7.37, every employer shall implement the provisions of sections 7.24 and 7.25 in respect of a hazardous product and may, in so doing, replace the generic name of the product with the brand name, chemical name, common name or trade name, if the hazardous product

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is present in the work place;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: was received from a supplier; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is one of the following:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a hazardous product, other than wood or a product made of wood, that is listed in Schedule 1 to the Hazardous Products Act,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a nuclear substance, as defined in section 2 of the Nuclear Safety and Control Act, that is radioactive.

Subsection.Text: All radioactive materials used in a work place shall be packaged, when not in use, in accordance with the requirements of the Transport Packaging of Radioactive Materials Regulations.

If a hazardous product, other than a hazardous product referred to in paragraph 7.28(1)(c), is received in the work place by an employer, the employer shall, without delay, obtain a supplier safety data sheet in respect of the hazardous product from the supplier, unless the employer is already in possession of a supplier safety data sheet that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is for a hazardous product that both has the same product identifier and is from the same supplier;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: discloses information that is current at the time that the hazardous product is received; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: was prepared and dated less than three years before the day on which the hazardous product is received.

Subsection.Text: If the supplier safety data sheet in respect of a hazardous product in a work place is three years old or more, the employer shall, if possible, obtain from the supplier a current supplier safety data sheet.

If it is not possible for an employer to obtain a current supplier safety data sheet, the employer shall update the hazard information on the most recent supplier safety data sheet that the employer has received, on the basis of the ingredients disclosed on that supplier safety data sheet and on the basis of any significant new data of which the employer is aware.

Subject to section 7.37, if an employer receives a supplier safety data sheet, the employer may prepare a work place safety data sheet to be used in the work place in place of the supplier safety data sheet if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the work place safety data sheet discloses at least the information disclosed on the supplier safety data sheet;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the information disclosed on the work place safety data sheet does not disclaim or contradict the information disclosed on the supplier safety data sheet;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the supplier safety data sheet is readily available for examination by the employees in any form, as determined in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the work place safety data sheet discloses that the supplier safety data sheet is available in the work place.

Subsection.Text: An employer shall review the accuracy of the information disclosed on a work place safety data sheet referred to in subsection (1) and update it as soon as practicable after new hazard information or significant new data becomes available to the employer.

If the information required to be disclosed on the work place safety data sheet is not available or not applicable to the hazardous product, the employer shall, in place of the information, insert the words “not available” or “not applicable”, as the case may be, in the English version and the words “non disponible” or “sans objet”, as the case may be, in the French version, of the work place safety data sheet.

Every employer shall keep readily available for examination by employees and by any policy committee, work place committee or the health and safety representative in any work place in which an employee is likely to handle or be exposed to a hazardous product a copy, in English and in French, of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an employer referred to in subsection 7.30(1), the work place safety data sheet; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, the supplier safety data sheet.

Subsection.Text: The work place safety data sheet and supplier safety data sheet shall be made available in any form, as determined in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative.

Subject to sections 7.33 and 7.34, each hazardous product, other than a hazardous product referred to in paragraph 7.28(1)(c), in a work place that is intended for use in the work place and each container in which the hazardous product is contained in a work place shall, if the hazardous product or the container was received from a supplier, have applied to it a supplier label.

Subject to sections 7.33, 7.34 and 7.37, if a hazardous product, other than a hazardous product referred to in paragraph 7.28(1)(c), is received from a supplier and an employer places the hazardous product in the work place in a container other than the container in which it was received from the supplier, the employer shall apply to the container a supplier label or work place label that discloses the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the product identifier;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the hazard information in respect of the hazardous product; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement indicating that a safety data sheet for the hazardous product is available in the work place.

Subsection.Text: Subject to sections 7.36 and 7.37, no person shall remove, deface, modify or alter the supplier label applied to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a hazardous product that is in the work place; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the container of a hazardous product that is in the work place.

Section.Text: Where an employer stores a hazardous product in the work place in a container that has applied to it a supplier label or a work place label, a portable container filled from that container does not have to be labelled in accordance with section 7.32 if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the hazardous product is required for immediate use; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the following conditions apply in respect of the hazardous product:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: it is under the control of and used exclusively by the employee who filled the portable container,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: it is used only during the work shift in which the portable container was filled, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: it is clearly identified by a work place label applied to the portable container that discloses the product identifier.

Section.Text: An employer shall, in a conspicuous place near a hazardous product, post a sign in respect of the hazardous product that discloses the product identifier if the hazardous product is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in a bulk shipment that is not placed in a container at the work place; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: not in a container and stored in bulk.

Section.Text: The information disclosed on a sign referred to in section 7.34 or paragraph 7.38(b) shall be of such a size that it is clearly legible to the employees in the work place.

Subsection.Text: If, in a work place, a label applied to a hazardous product or the container of a hazardous product becomes illegible or is removed from the hazardous product or the container, the employer shall replace the label with a work place label that discloses the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the product identifier;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the hazard information in respect of the hazardous product; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement indicating that a safety data sheet for the hazardous product is available in the work place.

Subsection.Text: An employer shall review the accuracy of the information on a work place label and update it as soon as practicable after new hazard information or significant new data becomes available to the employer.

Subject to subsection (2), if an employer has filed a claim for exemption from the requirement to disclose information on a safety data sheet or on a label under subsection 11(2) of the Hazardous Materials Information Review Act, the employer shall disclose, in place of the information that the employer is exempt from disclosing,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if there is no final disposition of the proceedings in relation to the claim, the date on which the claim for exemption was filed and the registry number assigned to the claim under section 10 of the Hazardous Materials Information Review Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the final disposition of the proceedings in relation to the claim is that the claim is valid, a statement that an exemption has been granted and the date on which the exemption was granted.
